So you were using the VM preference page to search for a JRE?

Please provide steps to reproduce. Is this still a problem in M3? (note that 
the stack trace looks unrelated to your problem description).

Still - I see nothing about a modal dialog box in this description. If you are 
launching a java process that goes into an infinite loop - that is the fault of 
the java process, not Eclipse.

Ahh, no, it's _not_ a program I'm developing.  As in the first discription of
this issue - when eclipse opens, it displays an "Operation in progress..." modal
which you can't escape from, or cancel. Once this begins to happen in eclipse,
there is no way to stop it from happening each time eclipse is run. I moved my
entire instillation to a backup folder and installed eclipse anew. The  freshly
installed version does not exibit the problem, while the backup version does.

I learned a bit more about eclipse, and I was able to see that it creates a
.lock file in the workspace/.metadata directory for this operation.

WORKAROUND:
I discovered a workaround while experimenting with my 'bad' version, trying to
gather more useful debugging information. If you run the application with the
below command, the modal box will not show, and the application will run,
however the CPU will still be heavily used by one of the java processes running
under eclipse:
./eclipse -refresh
After I got this working, I noticed that the Package Explorer was not behaving
correctly, the slider bar wold not move, and there was a lot of 'flicker' in the
  UI.
I closed the Package Explorer, and the CPU Utilization dropped to normal levels.
Upon closing eclipse, and re-running it normally. All was well!

Looking at my workspace settings, I see that I have Refresh Workspace on Startup
checked, which may or may not have something to do with it.

I hope helps.
-Kyle

Moving to JDT-UI for comment. This does not have anything to do with the 
debugger (it is not even active when the workspace is started).

Kyle,

we fixed some dead-locks for M3. Can you please try if the problem still 
exists under M3 build.

Since you can still reproduce it can you please provide a VM dump of the 
hanging VM. This would give use some more insights. You can produce a VM dump 
for most VM under Linux via kill - 3 'process number'

Unfortunately, since I did that workaroud, I've been unable to reproduce that
problem again... I don't know the exact scenario which caused the problem in the
first place. After I was able to launch the workspace and close the package
explorer the problem has not returned (even though I re-added the package explorer).

If I'm able to re-create it I'll try the VM Dump and send it out. As for trying
it under M3, since I'm not able to recreate the problem on demand, I'm not sure
it would help.

Thanks a lot,
-Kyle
OK, I will set the PR to remind.

It happened again, seemingly out of the blue - It ended up being the exact same
problem, (with the package explorer going out of control.) In the end, the
workaround I put in above allowed me to escape.

I'll keep this version around and get ahold of M3 to see if I see these types of
things.
Thanks,
-Kyle

Regarding M3...

I'm using M3 now, and I'm seeing an issue that does not manifest itself in the
same way, but I believe it has the same root cause, so I'm posting it here. I've
had it happen repetedly and I've taken some snapshots of the VM. Basically, the
problem is with the Package Explorer 'frezing' and not allowing the movement of
the slider bar and the CPU going to 100% usage. It's the same thing as in v2.1,
however if you close exlipse and re-open, the problem will go away. Also, since
t occurs mid-runing of eclipse rather than at startup, you can close the package
 explorer as an alternative to forcing eclipse down.

I can't tell what's initiating the problem, but here is the snapshot:

In all stack trace the main thread is in 
org.eclipse.swt.internal.gtk.OS.gtk_main_iteration and the other threads are 
waiting or sleeping. I remember that we say this behaviour when using an 
incorrect version of GTK (it happened when opening a dialog). Asking SWT for 
comments.
To SWT team: only comments #12, #13, #14 are relevant.
SSQ do you remember anything about this (comment 14)?

I believe this is the same problem as Bug#36698. Please take a look at it. If 
you are running Mandrake with GTK 2.2.1-mdk2, you will need to upgrade.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 36698 ***
